III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS & CONCLUSIONS
A. Physical Description of Facility
Bridgeway is a large three-story, brick commercial building with a private drive, large
parking area, and playground area. This thirty-six-bed facility is located on Burton Street
in Grand Rapids, Michigan. Upon entering the main door there is a large reception area
with a waiting area and two doors that lead to the main hallway. The first floor is made
up of several classrooms, case managers’ offices, a large kitchen, and dining room
area. The classrooms will be used by the Bridgeway residents as well as the children
through the Transitional Foster Care Program. The case managers’ office is a large
open space with cubical/desk space for the case managers of the Bridgeway program.
The dining room area has seating for approximately 50 and has several small tables
and chairs as well as booth like seating along the wall. The dining area is separated
from the kitchen area by a doorway and a large serving window that has a rolldown fire
door. The appliances are all new and commercial size to hold food for the entire school
and residential program.
The second and third floors are the exact same layout as each other, and are the living
areas for the residential program residents. Upon entering the floor from the north side
of the building there is a large open space that includes the living room area furnished
with a tv and living room furniture, a large staff desk equipped with a tv monitor that has
camera views of the entire facility, and a kitchenette area for snacks and beverages for
the residents. There is a long hallway which includes a locked laundry room, two large
bathrooms, eleven bedrooms, an office, and a recreational room. The laundry room is
the fifth door down the hallway on the left-hand side and holds two washers and two
2

dryers in order for staff to do the residents laundry. Off the laundry room is a locked
storage room where the facility will keep the resident medication in a locked cart,
therefore being locked behind three locks. The office is for staff and is the fourth room
down the hallway on the left-hand side. This office will have room for staff to keep
personal belongings and do the paperwork required of them. There are two bathrooms
one on each side of the hallway. The bathrooms have double sinks and mirrors in the
hallway area and a closed area that has a shower and toilet. The purpose of having the
bathrooms set up in this fashion is to allow a resident to be using the shower/toilet while
other residents are using the sink/mirrors. The resident rooms are set up in singles,
triples, and quadruples. The rooms all have large windows for natural lighting, single
beds or bunk beds, dressers, and wardrobes for hanging clothing. Each bedroom has
its own thermostat which the residents will be able to control within four degrees of the
set heat. The recreational room is the fourth room on the right and will be furnished with
a television and gaming system, and a foosball or air hockey table. There are exits
halfway down each hallway as well as at both the north and south end of the hallway.
An Environmental Health Inspection on October 18, 2019 resulted in an “A” rating, as
did the Fire Safety Inspection conducted on September 18, 2019.
B. Program Description
Bethany Christian Services’ Bridgeway Transitional Assessment Center program is a
nonprofit shelter program equipped to house single unaccompanied children whom are
seeking reunification with family/family friends in the United States. This program is a
36-bed shelter which serves males ages 12-17. The program cares for youth that may
be under socialized, have some history of alcohol or drug use/abuse but not currently
using, significant trauma experiences, history of psychiatric hospitalizations but currently
stable (no active psychotic episodes), history of some minor physical aggression
(including cruelty to animals) but not currently screened as a risk to self or others,
previous minor violations of the law, and poor academic performance or history of
truancy. The program is not designed for youth with histories of starting fires, active
psychotic episodes, active risk of harm to self, active risk of harm to others, significant
runaway risk, and/or current dependence on drugs or alcohol. Bridgeway residents will
be provided the following intensive services: Intensive case-management services,
Know Your Rights Presentation/Legal Screening provided by MIRC, On Site
Educational Programming, Recreation and Activity Therapy, Individual Therapy through
the Trauma Focused Cognitive Behavioral model, Group Counseling Session by onsite
Therapist, and Community and in-home Activities. The average length of stay would be
45 days.
During placement the youth are receiving 24/7 care, case management services, legal
services, educational services, counselling, and participate in recreational activities.
Residents will have an initial health screen within 24 hours of arriving to the program,
and a full medical physical exam by a local licensed physician within 48 hours of
admission which includes immunizations, TB test, and HIV testing. Residents will have
a dental exam after 70 days in care but prior to 90 days in care. Education will be
3

provided to residents onsite with a licensed teacher and staff members. Residents will
be enrolled no later than five school days following the youth’s arrival to the program
and will attend for six hours a day Monday-Friday.
Residents will have a case manager assigned to them and will meet their case manager
within 24 hours of intake and weekly thereafter. Residents will be assessed to
determine what kind of support is needed and a comprehensive treatment plan will be
tailored to each resident to meet those identified needs. Bridgeway will follow the
Sanctuary Model of Care, which is trauma responsive and has seven components,
including Nonviolence, Emotional Intelligence, Social Learning, Democracy, Open
Communication, Social Responsibility, and Growth and Change. Treatment for
residents will be goal-oriented and go beyond symptom reduction to address
impairments, skill deficits, and environmental problems that interfere with their ability to
function in all major areas of life.
The staff-to-resident ratio is 1:6 during waking hours and 1:12 during sleeping hours.
The facility will have no form of seclusion for the residents. Facility staff will be trained in
the use of CPI: Non-violent Crisis Intervention training for de-escalation and restraint
purposes.
C. Rule/Statutory Violations
This private child caring institution was in full compliance with all rules.
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Issuance of an original license to this private child caring institution is
recommended.
